form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Sullivan introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To amend the Higher Education Act of 1965 to prohibit institutions of higher education from receiving gifts from or entering into contracts with foreign countries of concern.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Securing Academia from Foreign Entanglements Act .

section.header: Funds from foreign countries of concern

subsection.text: Section 117(h)(2)(A) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1011f(h)(2)(A)) is amended by inserting , except that such term does not include a foreign country of concern as defined in section 117A after agency of a foreign government.

subsection.header: Prohibition on funds from foreign countries of concern
subsection.text: Title I of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 117 the following:

section.header: Prohibition on gifts from foreign countries of concern

paragraph.text: The term contract has the meaning given that term in section 117.
The term foreign country of concern includes the following:

subparagraph.text: A country that is a covered nation (as defined in section 4872(d) of title 10, United States Code).

Any country that the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State, and the Director of National Intelligence, determines to be engaged in conduct that is detrimental to the national security or foreign policy of the United States.

paragraph.text: The term gift has the meaning given that term in section 117.
The term institution has the meaning given that term in section 117.

subsection.text: An institution shall not receive a gift from or enter into a contract with a foreign country of concern.
This section shall not be construed to affect the payment of tuition, room and board, fees, or other aspects of cost of attendance.
